snippet.textDisplay: 1:28 What the fudge, i'm confused. When a vehicle brakes the front wheels are subjected to backward force as the vehicles momentum is pushing forward. That leads to the force trying to increase toe out, The very opposite of what he saying. What am I missing here??
snippet.textOriginal: 1:28 What the fudge, i'm confused. When a vehicle brakes the front wheels are subjected to backward force as the vehicles momentum is pushing forward. That leads to the force trying to increase toe out, The very opposite of what he saying. What am I missing here??

snippet.textDisplay: Here's the thing, toe out makes the steering more twitchy, great for corners but a nightmare in a straight line, needed constant steering adjustments, you want toe in for stability, which is why road cars typically have 1-1.5 degrees toe in, and it's this toe in which help centre the steering.
snippet.textOriginal: Here's the thing, toe out makes the steering more twitchy, great for corners but a nightmare in a straight line, needed constant steering adjustments, you want toe in for stability, which is why road cars typically have 1-1.5 degrees toe in, and it's this toe in which help centre the steering.

snippet.textDisplay:
This seems daft if this is actually how it's implemented.
It would make a lot more sense to have the the toe out initiated by the driver pushing the column forward under braking given he's gonna be pushed forward under braking anyway.
Having the driver pull the whole time is just stupid. Initiate the toe in in the braking zone and then remove it when he wants to accelerate when he's pushed back in his seat moving out of the turn.
I hope the commentator has got the wrong end of the stick or maybe this a troll from the team to see what the other teams do.
No F1 team would make a system like this surely.
Maybe I've missed something?
Educate me.
Is the thinking just that the straights a but more relaxed from driver attention pov.
Maybe some corners are just too much already to worry about.
I'm spitballing here.
Luv and Peace.

snippet.textDisplay: I believe this was already outlawed in the 2021 regs, so it won't be on the 2021 cars. I believe Article 10.5.2 says: "The re-alignment of the steered wheels, as defined by the position of the inboard attachment of the relevant suspensions members that remain a fixed distance from each other, must be uniquely defined by a monotonic function of the rotational position of a single steering wheel."
snippet.textOriginal: I believe this was already outlawed in the 2021 regs, so it won't be on the 2021 cars. I believe Article 10.5.2 says: "The re-alignment of the steered wheels, as defined by the position of the inboard attachment of the relevant suspensions members that remain a fixed distance from each other, must be uniquely defined by a monotonic function of the rotational position of a single steering wheel."

snippet.textDisplay: I’m not sure I agree with Marko on the adjustment of ride height. The contact patch remains the same as it’s toe in and out that’s adjusted not the vertical angle of the tyre. Yes under steering it changes but I can’t see it changing with a degree or so of toe in and out as it’s on the centre of the tyre where the shape or profile of the tyre remains the same. Of course he’s going to shout foul, they didn’t think of it. I remember Christian Horner complaining that it wasn’t right that Mercedes won everything and made it boring. Funny, I don’t remember him saying that when Redbull and Vettel were winning everything in sight. 🙄
snippet.textOriginal: I’m not sure I agree with Marko on the adjustment of ride height. The contact patch remains the same as it’s toe in and out that’s adjusted not the vertical angle of the tyre. Yes under steering it changes but I can’t see it changing with a degree or so of toe in and out as it’s on the centre of the tyre where the shape or profile of the tyre remains the same. Of course he’s going to shout foul, they didn’t think of it. I remember Christian Horner complaining that it wasn’t right that Mercedes won everything and made it boring. Funny, I don’t remember him saying that when Redbull and Vettel were winning everything in sight. 🙄

snippet.textDisplay: weird, for 40 years i have always thought that under hard braking the front wheels want to splay backwards and TOE OUT !! not toe-in under braking !!  You want toe out on cornering as it helps the ackerman angle , basically the wheel on the corner you are about to go round is already facing that way already before you even start to turn.
snippet.textOriginal: weird, for 40 years i have always thought that under hard braking the front wheels want to splay backwards and TOE OUT !! not toe-in under braking !! snippet.textDisplay:
If they are going to ban it they should do it this season and give reasons why. Otherwise it should be allowed in perpertuity. The main argument for banning it is that it is an extra cost which adds little performance advantage. If all the teams have to implement their own system the cost will hit the smallest teams hardest.


This may help prodice closer racing if implemented by all as it may be able to be used to reduce tyre wear when following cars.

snippet.textDisplay: Off-road construction site vehicles such as tractors, fork-lift trucks, dumper trucks, etc., have been using adjustable toe systems for decades, and it has taken F1 about as long to latch onto this idea as it took them to start using dual-clutch gear boxes for faster and smoother gear changes. Advances in vehicle engineering have always followed the pattern of tractors, lorries, cars, and they probably always will do. Ploughing a field isn't as exciting as an F1 race though so I will keep on following F1.
snippet.textOriginal: Off-road construction site vehicles such as tractors, fork-lift trucks, dumper trucks, etc., have been using adjustable toe systems for decades, and it has taken F1 about as long to latch onto this idea as it took them to start using dual-clutch gear boxes for faster and smoother gear changes. Advances in vehicle engineering have always followed the pattern of tractors, lorries, cars, and they probably always will do. Ploughing a field isn't as exciting as an F1 race though so I will keep on following F1.

snippet.textDisplay:
It's interesting to note that even on their long race runs this week I haven't seen any blistering on the inside shoulder of the Merc tyres, which happened at loads of races last year.

Now they haven't been using DAS on every lap and/or straight but it definitely looks like they have improved their front tyre wear and decreased front tyre damage on this years car through DAS and probably a hundred other slight changes to their front suspension 👏👏👏
snippet.textOriginal:
It's interesting to note that even on their long race runs this week I haven't seen any blistering on the inside shoulder of the Merc tyres, which happened at loads of races last year.

Now they haven't been using DAS on every lap and/or straight but it definitely looks like they have improved their front tyre wear and decreased front tyre damage on this years car through DAS and probably a hundred other slight changes to their front suspension 👏👏👏

snippet.textDisplay: I'm all for innovation and forward thinking if it makes for closer racing but how has this piece of innovation got anything to with that? All I can see is increasing one particular team's dominance for some time and cost increases for every team, as they will all have to follow suit in order to keep up, thus leaving the smaller teams even less money in their budgets for actually closing the gap. DAS has apparently already been outlawed for next year so it just seems like a colossal waste of money, time and effort, especially as they keep bleating on about having to have rubbish sounding engines to improve road cars, I would like to know how this particular design might do this? FIA should have put their foot down and said no, altering the suspension geometry after parc ferme is not allowed, who ever or what ever is doing it.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm all for innovation and forward thinking if it makes for closer racing but how has this piece of innovation got anything to with that? All I can see is increasing one particular team's dominance for some time and cost increases for every team, as they will all have to follow suit in order to keep up, thus leaving the smaller teams even less money in their budgets for actually closing the gap. DAS has apparently already been outlawed for next year so it just seems like a colossal waste of money, time and effort, especially as they keep bleating on about having to have rubbish sounding engines to improve road cars, I would like to know how this particular design might do this? FIA should have put their foot down and said no, altering the suspension geometry after parc ferme is not allowed, who ever or what ever is doing it.

snippet.textDisplay: As a fan of f1 what I want to see is teams focusing on clever developments like this, making the sport more interesting  and unique without whining and attempting to ban systems that give opposing teams an advantage. Remember the 60’s/ 70’s and 80’s those eras were very interesting because so many cars on the grid would look so different o one another. Teams trying out all kinds of wacky innovations in a proverbial arms race to see what works and where they can gain an innovative advantage. Instead of trying to find an illegality in an opposing teams new system, come up with your own counterpart and see who gets there most effectively, that’s interesting and exciting for fans
snippet.textOriginal: As a fan of f1 what I want to see is teams focusing on clever developments like this, making the sport more interesting  and unique without whining and attempting to ban systems that give opposing teams an advantage. Remember the 60’s/ 70’s and 80’s those eras were very interesting because so many cars on the grid would look so different o one another. Teams trying out all kinds of wacky innovations in a proverbial arms race to see what works and where they can gain an innovative advantage. Instead of trying to find an illegality in an opposing teams new system, come up with your own counterpart and see who gets there most effectively, that’s interesting and exciting for fans
